Cluster architecture will enable companies to manage multiple operating systems on a single server, which will save costs and improve efficiency, says IBM
IBM announced its new cluster architecture that will enable companies manage multiple operating system on a single system, which will lead to cost saving and improved efficiency. The cluster comprises of IBM’s Opter on based eServer 85 server, and systems management and storage devices, which can run on multiple operating systems including Linux, Windows and z/VM.
IBM said its new cluster technology will enable clients to manage multiple OS' on a single physical box, which will reduce costs and improve flexibility. The new cluster architecture provides better utilization of IT resources by allowing multiple operating systems to be run on a single hardware platform, which will result in significant cost savings.

company made the decision to end support for Allo due to limited adoption and use compared to other messaging platforms.
Allo was designed to compete with popular messaging apps like WhatsApp, Facebook Messenger and Apple’s iMessage. But despite its innovative features such as smart replies, incognito mode, and group selfie mode, Allo struggled to gain traction with users.
In a statement, Google said: “We understand that Allo didn’t gain as much traction as we had hoped. We’re always looking at how we can improve our products and services, and decide to stop supporting Allo.
“We want to thank everyone who used Allo and provided feedback over the past two years. Your support means a lot to us, and we’re sorry that we couldn’t make it work out.”
Google will shut down Allo on March 25, 2019. Users

Lew reiterated his call for Congress to act quickly to address the issue, which he said had "grown more pressing" as the government approaches its $18.1 trillion borrowing limit.
"The sooner Congress acts, the better," he said. "It's important for Congress to address this issue before it becomes a crisis."
Lawmakers have been deadlocked on how to raise the borrowing limit without also approving significant spending cuts or policy changes, which has raised fears of a default.

, missed it, ICYMI is shorthand for "In Case You Missed It." This handy acronym serves as a convenient way to inform others of something they might have overlooked or forgotten.
ICYMI has become increasingly popular as a way to bring attention to important news, events, or messages, particularly in online communities, social media, and other digital platforms. It's a versatile term that can be used in a variety of contexts, from casual conversations to professional communications and even in academic or technical writing.
As with any term, however, there are certain nuances to be aware of when using ICYMI. For example, while it can be used as a standalone statement, it's more common to follow it with a brief explanation or summary of what you're referring to, to help others quickly understand the context. General Government Structural Budget Balance (%) for Israel in years 2001-2014 is -1.331 %.
The structural budget balance is defined as the difference between total government net lending/borrowing and potential GDP growth, expressed as a percentage of potential GDP.
Structural budget balance, expressed as % of GDP, measures the difference between government net lendings/borrowings and potential Gross Domestic Product (GDP). This indicates the extent to which fiscal policy contributes to or detracts from the overall stability of the economy. A structural budget surplus (or a smaller deficit) tends to support stability and economic growth, while a larger deficit may indicate a need for tightening

, Harry has recently returned to the series with a new novel, Twenty Palances: The Oracle. Here are my spoiler-free thoughts on the novel.
I have been a fan of Harry Connoly's Tweny Palaces series since the first novel, Game of Cages. In that novel, Harry introduced us to a complex world with a unique magic system and a protagonist who struggles to come to terms with his abilities. In each subsequent novel, Harry has expanded on this world, adding new characters and plotlines while deepening our understanding of the magic system and its limitations.
Twenty Palaces: The Oracle picks up where the previous novel, The Great Reverie, left off. Cricket is a game of nuance, a game where every decision, every ball, every run matters. And yet, cricket books are often heavy on statistics and light on insight. Not here. In “The Art of Cricket,” writer and cricketer Rohan Chandran captures the game’s subtleties with a keen eye and a light touch.
Chandran’s prose is elegant, his turns of phrase both precise and evocative. He describes a ball’s trajectory as “a slow, lazy arc,” and a batsman’s defenses as “a delicate dance.” He captures the rhythms of the game, the way bat and ball intertwine, each informing the other.
But “The Art Of Cricket” is more than just a cricket book. It’s a meditation on the nature of art, of creativity, of the way we express ourselves.

The regulation, issued by the Ministry of Information, Culture and Tourism, prohibits reporters from entering restricted areas without prior approval, and from using cameras or other recording equipment without permission. over, the oath of office doesn't require a president to actively seek to overturn Supreme Court decisions with which they disagree.
In fact, presidents have sworn to "take this obligation freely, without any mental reservation or purpose of evasion."
That means they have a duty to uphold the Constitution and laws, even if they don't personally agree with them.
And, of course, the Supreme Court itself has the power to interpret the Constitution and overturn previous rulings, should they be convinced that a prior decision was erroneous.
In short, the Constitution is the supreme law of the land, and presidents have a duty under their oath ofoffice to uph oldit and defend it, even when they disagree with Supreme Court ruli ings.

peppers come in a variety of colors. They can be green, red, orange, yellow or a combination of these colors. Jalapeno plants are relatively compact, reaching heights of 18 to 36 inches (45 to 90 cm) and are suitable for container growing. Chianti Classico is produced only in the Chianti region of Tuscany, and is subject to strict rules of production, including a minimum aging requirement of at least six months in oak barrels. This aging requirement allows the wine to develop a rich, complex flavor profile that is perfectly suited to autumn.

ining the detector.  Image credit: Fermilab.
Physicists at the Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory (FNAL) have detected a high-energy neutrino using the Deep Underground Neutrino Experiment (DUNE), located at the Sanford Underground Research Facility in Lead, South Dakota. This is the first time a neutrino has been detected with such precision, and it could provide significant insights into the nature of these elusive particles.
Neutrinos are subatomic particles that are created in the cores of stars, including the sun, and are abundant in the universe. However, they are very difficult to detect because they interact very weakly with matter, making them almost invisible to detection.
The DUNE experiment uses a tank of liquid argon as a target material to detect neutrinos. When a neutrido passes through the liquid argon, it

drought, which means we are in a period of below-average precipitation. But, as any hydrologist will tell you, drought is a complex and multifaceted phenomenon that involves much more than just precipitation. In this column, I'll explore some of the other factors that contribute to a drought, and how they interact with precipitation to create the conditions we experience.
One important factor in determining whether or not we are in drought is soil moisture. When soils are dry and lacking moisture, they are less able to absorb and hold water, which can lead to runoff and erosion. So, even if we are getting plenty of precipitation, if the soils are already dry, we may still experience drought conditions. ity, as well as one of the most influential thinkers in the development of Neoplatonism. Proclus was born in Constantinople but spent most of his life in Athens, where he studied and taught philosophy. He was a student of Marinus, the head of the Neoplatonic school in Athens. Proclus’s extensive writings cover a wide range of philosophical topics, including metaphysics, cosmology, ethics, and theology. He developed a system of thought that emphasized the interconnectedness of philosophy and religion, as well asthe unity of the universe.
In his work “On the Nature of the Universe,” Proclus presented a comprehensive and systematic exposition of his cosmological views. He posited that the universe consists of multiple levels of reality, with each level corresponding to a different aspect of reality. This hierarchy of levels, which he called the “ecclesiastical hierarchy of being,”

In the wake of the latest round of racial violence and discrimination, I have been asked by many of my students of color, “Should I give up on white people?”
My response is always the same: “Never.”
I understand the despair and frustration that can come from feeling marginalized and oppressed by a dominant group, but I believe that giving up on an entire group of people is both unjust and unwise.
First, it is important to recognize that not all white people are the same. While some may actively perpetuate systemic racism, many others are actively working against it. We must avoid generalizing and stereotyping entire groups of people based on the actions of a few.

A new study published in the journal Nature uses a technique called X-ray micro-computed tomography (micro-CT) to image tiny structures within a living cancer cell. The technique works by taking thousands of X-ray images of the cell from different angles and then using computer algorithms to reconstruct a 3D model of the internal structures.
"This technology has the potential to revolutionize the way we understand the biology of cancer cells," said study author Dr. Haiquiang Yang, a researcher at the University of Pennsylvania. "By visualizing the internal structures of cancer cells with such high resolution, we can gain new insights into how these cells function and how they respond to different treatments."

On January 12, 2010, a devastating earthquake struck Haiti, causing widespread destruction and loss of life. The quake measured 7.0 on the Richter scale, making it one of the worst natural disasters in recent history. As aid organizations and governments around the world responded to the crisis, a new challenge emerged: how to provide adequate housing and shelter for the hundreds of thousands of survivors who had lost their homes.

somewhat eerie, poem from Walt Whitman’s “Song of Myself” (1855):

“Do I contradict myself? / Very well, then I contradict myself,
(I am large, I contain multitudes.)”

These lines have taken a life of their own, becoming a cultural touchstone. We’ve heard them referenced in countless TV shows and movies, from “The Office” to “The Big Lebowski,” from “Breaking Bad” to “Parks and Recreation.” They’ve been used to describe anything from political campaigns to personal struggles to life philosophies.

And yet, do we really know what Whitman meant? Or are we just using his lines to justify our own contradictory beliefs and actions?

This is a classic example of a phishing scam. The email or message that the person received was designed to trick them into revealing their credit card information, which was then used to make fraudulent purchases.
The amount listed on the bill, $23143,83, is a common amount used in these types of scams. It is likely that the scammer created a fake website or message that looked legitimate in order to fool the person into entering their credit card number.
It is important to always be cautious when receiving unsolicited messages or emails that request personal financial information. of Queen — hit theaters, moviegoers were treated to a film that was both heart-warming and heart-wrenching. The film, directed by Bryan Singer, chronicles the life of Mercury, from his childhood to his meteoric rise to fame with Queen, to his personal struggles and tragic death at the age of 45 due to complications from AIDS.
One of the most impressive aspects of the film is its commitment to accuracy. The filmmakers worked closely with Mercury’s family and bandmates to ensure that the film was as authentic as possible. This attention to detail pays off in the film’s performances, which capture the energy and spirit of Queen’s live shows. Rami Malek, who plays Mercury, gives a performance that is both powerful and nuanced, fully inhabiting the character and bringing him to life in a way that feels both intimate and universal.

Tamar Epstein, the estranged wife of Rabbi Avrohom Moses, has remarried, without obtaining an Orthodox divorce (Get). While her new union has triggered controversy within the Orthodox Jewish community, experts say her remarriage may be legal and valid under secular Jewish law.

, Ireland will not have any soldiers serving in a United Nations peacekeeping mission.
The 146th Irish contingent, which included soldiers, officers and medical personnel, returned home earlier today after completing their deployment in Chad.
Since 1980, Ireland has been actively involved in UN peacekeeping missions, with over 120,000 Irish personnel serving in more than 30 different missions around the world.
Irish Defence Force chief General Patrick Blair said: “This is a significant moment in the history of Irish peacekeeper. While we are sad to see our deployment in ChAd come to an end, we are proud of the work our troops have done in support of peace and security in the region.
“We will continue to support UN peacekeepingo and will assess the possibility of future deployments as the situation develops.”

(AP) - When shopping for botanical products like supplements or skin care products, some experts say a simple DNA test may not be enough to ensure their authenticity.
That's because DNA tests can only identify the plant species, not verify the specific strain or quality of the plant material. And, some experters say, some companies may try to pass off lower-quality or fake plants as a more expensive or exclusive strain.
"It's a problem," said Dr. Drew Tortorici, a botanist at Cornell University. "A lot of people are getting ripped off."
Tortorici and other experts say that while DNA tests can help identify the plant material, other tests are needed to ensure quality and authenticity. For example, chemica analytical tests can identify the presence of specific compounds, like flavonoids or alkaloids, that are associated with a particular plant species.

3 How to Become a Web Hosting Reseller.
There are two types of web hosting services, shared hosting and dedicated hosting. A shared hosting provider offers server space and bandwidth to multiple customers, each running their own website, but sharing the same server resources. On the other hand, a dedicated hosting provider offers a dedicated server, which means that the customer has their own physical server and resources, such as CPU, RAM and bandwidth.
A reseller hosting provider sits between these two models, renting backend server space and resources from larger hosting companies and then reselling those resources to their customers under their own brand, at a profit.
In essence a reseller hosting business is buying hosting space from other hosting providers, then re-selling it with their own branding, support and customization, while paying a wholesale fee to the hosting provider they are reselling from. 15 minutes of yoga practice per day can improve cognitive flexibility and memory in healthy adults.

new riverfront park in Cleveland has received a $1.3 million grant from the National Park Service, the organization announced Monday.
The grant will be used to help fund the construction of Rivergate Park, a new 14-acre park located along the Cuyahoga River in Cleveland's Central Neighhood. The park is expected to include a public plaza, a riverfront promenade, a playground, a picnic area, and a kayak launch.
"We are thrilled to receive this grant from the NPS, which will help us make Rivergate Park a vibrant and accessible space for the entire community," said Dan Kiley, executive director of the Cleveland RowingFoundation. The ClevelandRowing Foundation is working in partnership with the City of Cleveland, the Cleveland Metroparks, and other local organizations to develop the park.

A landslide on Thursday at the Hpakant jade mine in Kachin state trapped dozens of workers, many of whom were from neighboring Shan state. Rescuers have been working around the clock to locate the trapped workers, but their efforts have been hampered by difficult terrain and a lack of advanced equipment.
Police said Sunday that they had called off the search due to bad weather and the difficulty of reaching the site, which is located in a remote, mountainous area.
"We had to call off the search because of bad weather and difficult terrain," said Police Col. Phone Tint. "We couldn't reach the site even with military vehicles and equipment. It's very difficult to get there."
Phone Tint said that rescuers had been able to locate some of the workers' bodies, but he did not have an exact number.

from The Guardian reveals the mystery behind his disappearance:
Pat Maloney was playing at a show at the San Francisco Tape Music Center in 1980. That night, he left the stage in the middle of his performance and never came back. He was last seen walking into a convenience store, where he allegedly asked for a pack of cigarettes. But he never returned to his music.
Maloney had been a key figure in the experimental music scene in San Francisco, where he was known for his innovative use of electronic instruments and his ability to blend elements of jazz, rock, and classical music. He had released several albums and had performed at festivals around the world.
But after he vanished, Maloney's music was largely forgotten, until recently when a cache of his unreleased recordings were discovered.

cause cancer, and red meat likely does so too.
The France-based International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC), part of the WHO, put processed meats on the top of their “things that cause cancer list”, grouping them alongside tobacco, asbestos and diesel fumes, for which there is “sufficient evidence” of cancer links.
Along the years, there have been many studies that linked processed and red meats with cancer (especially bowel cancer), but there were always some doubts floating about. Now, the 22-member panel analyzed animal experiments, studies of human diet and health, and cell mechanisms that could lead from these meats to cancer.
“These findings further support current public health recommendations to limit intake of meat,” Dr. Christopher Wild, who directs IARC, said in a statement.

The reason for this has little to do with the attractiveness of EM investments. On the contrary, EM economic growth is at its lowest level since the 2008/09 financial crisis while the prospect of a U.S. monetary tightening creates the potential for financial turbulence.
The force propelling pension funds and insurance companies into unfamiliar EM investments is simple. If they stay at home, their investment returns are at risk of falling short of their liabilities.

The United States is not the first place that springs to mind when considering women dying in childbirth. So the fact that two American women die of pregnancy-related causes every day may come as a surprise.
According to the World Bank, The US ranks 50th in maternal mortality globally - falling behind every other industrialised nation. A woman in the US is as likely to suffer a maternal death as a woman in sanctions-hit Iran, and four times as likely as a woman in Germany.
"It is a preventable health issue," said Amnesty International's Rachel Ward. "It isn't something that we're waiting for a cure for. We’re waiting for political will."
What's worse is that US maternal mortality rates may actually be on the rise. Eugene Declercq, of Boston University's School of Public Health, produced a short film

friendly future.
Making the less-noxious food cart into an art.
There are 5,000 licensed food carts in New York, and they’re as much of an urban icon as the MTA’s subway signage or the Chrysler building. Too bad they’re killing the planet.
It’s not the food—the grub is OK, if not exactly slimming; it’s the gas generators powering the carts. Most food carts run off a diesel generator that’s designed to run only a few hours. Vendors run them for stretches of up to 14 hours, leading to a high output of greenhouse-gas emissions such as carbon monoxide, nitrous oxide, and particulate matter. spent 10 weeks in Europe, beginning with a six-week law-school summer session at Charles University in Prague.
Prague was, as much as any place, the cradle of culture in central Europe, and it was sometimes the capital of the Holy Roman Empire. Its ancient center was architecturally and many other ways romantic and gorgeous. Because it was subject only to rather minor bombing, Prague’s charm and beauty were nearly unscathed by World War II.
But 45 years of socialist “compassion” under a Soviet Union puppet regime had turned everything soot gray and ugly before eastern and central Europe was liberated in 1989.

Neither the green economy nor alternative sources of energy can prevent global warming. Solutions will come from concerted actions at the local and national levels, from the adoption of instruments and practices borrowed from other disciplines like peacebuilding, and from the move to a “no-waste economy”, according to experts here.
In its milestone report, “The Limits to Growth”, published in 1972, the Club of Rome warned that the human ecological footprint had grown dangerously quickly from 1900 to 1972. Shortly thereafter, the warning proved to be prophetic: by 1986 the human ecological footprint had overshot the carrying capacity of the Earth. At current production and consumption levels, we need 1.5 planets to survive; if everyone lived like a U.S. citizen, we would need five planets.

Donnelly Park is a peaceful park in the middle of town. It's popular with families looking to spend some time by the water, under the trees.

"I thought it was pretty messed up. I don't understand why people would do that," Turlock resident Tyler White said.
So the group cut the ducks free.

The Generation Energy report was produced by an advisory committee appointed by Mr. Carr after he hosted a conference last year on the need for a new Canadian energy strategy. The committee included representatives from the oil and gas industry and the electricity sector, as well as from clean energy and Indigenous organizations.
The panel declared that climate change is a growing danger, and that Canada must be part of a global transition to lower-carbon energy needed to avert the most catastrophic impacts.

The 39-year-old correspondent was detained in late July of last year, along with his wife and two photojournalists. Firefighters arrived at the three-story building on the 6700 block of South Dorchester Avenue two minutes after receiving calls of a fire, officials said. Three-year-old Maqkwone Jones was pulled from a second floor apartment and rushed to Comer Children's Hospital after suffering from cardiac arrest. He later died in the hospital.
The three-story building was mostly unoccupied at the time of the fire, according to the Chicago Fire Department, with people living in two of the 16 units. Thick, dark smoke could be seen from a distance as firefighters worked to stop the flames from jumping to neighboring buildings. In total, more than 100 firefighters joined in battling the blaze.
“The flames were just everywhere. It looked like it was spreading from the building to the next building over," Ryan Booker, a neighbor, said.

ining the detector walls, showcase the successful methodology of neutrino astronomy. This image shows multiple events.
Sometimes, the best-designed experiments fail. The effect you're looking for might not even occur, meaning that a null result should always be a possible outcome you're prepared for. When that happens, the experiment is often dismissed as a failure, even though you never would have known the results without performing it.
Yet, every once in a while, the apparatus that you build might be sensitive to something else entirely. When you do science in a new way, at a new sensitivity, or under new, unique conditions, that's often where the most surprising, serendipitous discoveries are made. In 1987, a failed experiment for detecting proton decay detected neutrinos, for the first time, from beyond not only our Solar System, but from outside of the Milky

puzzle: The National Weather Service says this is the wettest August since records began being kept 150 years ago, yet the National Weather Service also says the region is “abnormally dry,” the first stage of its drought-measurement scale.
No, climate change hasn’t driven weather folks crazy. The solution to the puzzle is that there are droughts and then there are droughts.
“There is a time lapse in how different systems respond to current conditions,” is how Richard Kiah, chief of Hydrologic Network Operations for the regional office of the U.S. Geological Survey, puts it.

ry between a warlord and a conjurer in 1920s China.
Too many potions muddle the alchemy in “The Great Magician,” a picaresque romance set around the rivalry between a warlord and a conjurer in 1920s China. Absent the psychological tension, technical showmanship and stylistic sleight-of-hand of “The Prestige,” this yarn from Hong Kong writer-helmer Derek Yee is unable to harmonize a mix of political intrigue and vaudevillian humor, while an excess of magic acts keeps the sterling cast too physically busy to breathe feeling into their roles. Out of touch with contempo urban tastes, the pic is unlikely to conjure dazzling B.O. in China or satisfy overseas cravings for martial arts-centric titles.

The Port Tracker report forecasts containerized imports to North Europe ports will contract 0.8 percent, to 14.89 million 20-foot-equivalent units. Exports from the ports are forecast to drop 1.7 percent, to 11.74 million TEUs.

, work or study in Canada, if they don’t want to be turned away at the border.
Currently, foreign nationals are required to obtain pre-authorization to travel to Canada by air, and the biometric check on arrival is an extra step to confirm a person seeking admission is really the same pre-screened individual on the travel documents.
“Biometric screening has proven effective in protecting the safety and security of Canadians and the integrity of the immigration system. Systematic fingerprint verification allows border service officers to confirm a traveller’s identity,” said Immigration Department spokesperson Shannon Kerr.
“Biometric screening has also made it easier to identify known criminals at the earliest opportunity in order to prevent them from coming to Canada. It has made it more difficult for others to forge, steal or use another person’s identity to gain access to Canada,” Kerr added.

Those original descendants, countless generations ago, jumping from one island to the next, found a home in Kei. They brought religion and culture to a truly remote part of the world, a paradise that largely still exists in raw form.
Where Bali has exploded into one of the world’s best known holiday escapes, Kei’s location - closer to Darwin in Australia than Jakarta - has left it in a long shadow. From a state of seclusion adrift in the Banda Sea, the islands’ magic has been left untapped.

Death-row inmates Alan Walker, Paul Woodward, Earl Berry, Dale Bishop and Gerald Holland sued the state in October 2007, claiming that the lethal-injection procedure constituted cruel and unusual punishment. Berry and Bishop have been executed since the filing.
The 5th Circuit said their complaint is time-barred, because the procedure could be challenged as early as 1997, and the state never hid its lethal-injection procedure. The limitation period for the inmates’ actions accrues from the date of their convictions and sentencing, the court ruled, or when the state changes its execution procedure. The cause of male pattern baldness is well established as an act of nature not nurture. Identical twins go bald at the same age, rate and pattern, irrespective of diet, lifestyle or stress levels.
There's no need to go bald any more.
Baldness is a complex polygenic trait: up to five genes are involved, and it is the interplay between these genes, not unlike the interaction between the cards in a poker hand, that determine the specifics of male pattern hair loss.
So, what are the treatment options?
Finasteride is a Therapeutic Goods Administration-approved drug that dermatologists and general practitioners have been prescribing to treat hair loss for about 15 years.
It works by stopping the conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone in the pro

more carbon dioxide enters the atmosphere, the global ocean soaks up much of the excess, storing roughly 30 percent of the carbon dioxide emissions coming from human activities.
In this sense, the ocean has acted as a buffer to slow down the greenhouse gas accumulation in the atmosphere and, thus, global warming. However, this process also increases the acidity of seawater and can affect the health of marine organisms and the ocean ecosystem.
New research by University of Delaware oceanographer Wei-Jun Cai and colleagues at Université Libre de Bruxelles, Texas A&M University-Corpus Christi, University of Hawaii at Manoa and ETH Zurich, now reveals that the water over the continental shelves is shouldering a larger portion of the load, taking up more and more of this atmospheric carbon dioxide.

Remember those X-ray glasses advertised in the back of comic books? Imagine a handheld camera that can reveal the unseen, inner structures of everything from concrete bridges to body parts.
Researchers at Missouri University of Science and Technology under engineering professor Reza Zoughi have developed a patented device that can show the inner structures of objects in real time by using millimeter and microwave signals.
Potential applications include the detection of cancerous skin cells, termite damage to buildings, or concealed weapons at secure zones like airports.
The tech could also be used for finding "defects in thermal insulating materials that are found in spacecraft heat insulating foam and tiles, space habitat structures, aircraft radomes and composite-strengthened concrete bridge members," Zoughi was quoted as saying in a release.

Port-au-Prince, Haiti (CNN) -- Haiti's capital seemed to spring back to life Wednesday, more than a week after a 7.0-magnitude earthquake flattened many parts of the city and killed tens of thousands.
Electrical power was still out most places, but traffic lights were functioning and chaotic traffic clogged many streets. Aid trucks, some guarded by blue-helmeted United Nations peacekeepers, were seen leaving the airport. Water trucks also were spotted in parts of Port-au-Prince.
"There's energy in the air," said Haitian-born J.B. Diederich, who lives in Miami but returned to Haiti for a few days after the earthquake.
More U.N. convoys were seen moving through the city

accurate warning about the spread of non-existent malware that claims a girl committed suicide over a post her father wrote on her Facebook wall.
No such tragedy has occurred but many are forwarding the wrong-headed message (extract below) creating confusion in the process.
People are passing on the warning in the mistaken belief they are helping Facebook friends to avoid a threat. In reality, they are spreading a hoax about a non-existent virus infection. The bogus warning is arguably causing more of a nuisance than a genuine malware infection, according to net security firm Sophos.
It adds that miscreants have exploited the confusion created by the warning by establishing Facebook pages that supposedly offer pictures from the fictitious girl's Facebook wall, but are really designed to make money by tricking surfers into wasting their time completing online surveys of dubious merit.

Getting rid of managers may seem like just another tech trend, but much of the skepticism around going “bossless” or flat is due to misleading terminology. We don’t quite have a good vocabulary for it yet — no managers doesn’t mean no management, and flat structure doesn’t mean everyone has equal sway.
Power, leadership, and even hierarchy still exist in these alternative structures, but instead of running along career ladders and hanging out in corner offices, they tend to be decentralized and dynamic rather than static and top-down.

Dallas shooter Micah Johnson’s attacks towards law enforcement have incited a new wave of anti-Black Lives Matter declarations by former New York mayor Rudy Giuliani and others, who have called the group “inherently racist.” They believe BLM is, in part, to blame for the deaths of the five police officers.

: My college-age nephew confided in me that he is gay.
I was very surprised. I am OK with his sexuality. It is his own business and no one else’s.
My nephew hasn’t told his parents, and he isn’t sure when he will.
I told him that we all love him just as he is and that this would not matter to anyone, but I don’t know that for a fact. I am pretty sure there are family members who would be upset.
As his aunt, am I supposed to talk (confidentially) to my brother and his wife, and ask for their understanding?
Or should I keep my nephew’s secret until he is ready to tell them himself?
Generally, I would ask my sisters, mother or husband for advice, but this is just not their business. My instinct is to keep his confession a secret.

If the gospel were being written today, perhaps it would be called the parable of the man who built his house on riparian land.
The images we have seen of expensive buildings being knocked down and cleared away are certainly shocking. It seems such a waste.
And of course, in the parable, it is slightly different, for it is the forces of nature that come and wash away the man’s house, not the forces of some government agency as has been seen in recent times.
Couldn’t they be made to pay a fine instead? Couldn’t the building be repossessed or nationalised? Could this situation have been avoided?
Well, perhaps. The truth is that this situation could have been avoided - by not building on riparian land without permission.
It’s as simple as that. No one just starts building without some sort of plan.

improvement in this key public health metric has plateaued.
New data released by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention shows there was no change in the national rate of infant mortality between 2014 and 2015, the most recent years for which it has published numbers.
South Carolina has a middling rate overall, compared to other states. The Palmetto State came in at 16th worst of 50 states and Washington D.C., with 6.74 infants dying each year before they reached 1 year old.
The infant mortality rate is considered an important community health measurement and is widely accepted as a key public health metric. The lower the rate, the better. In a study released this week, scientists said elephant genes may provide a crucial clue in the fight against human cancer.
The mammoth mammals rarely get cancer, which has long bewildered scientists considering elephants have 100 times as many cells as humans.
“They should be 100 times more likely to have a cell slip into a cancerous state and trigger the disease over their long life span of 50 to 70 years,” scientists at the University of Utah said.
Yet they don’t. The cancer mortality rate for elephants is less than 5% compared with 25% in people, the study said.
A team of scientists from the University of Utah and Arizona State University said they can explain the lower numbers.

Arctic Climate System (ACSYS) Historical Ice Chart Archive. The earliest chart in the data set comes from 1553, when Sir Hugh Willoughby and Richard Chancellor, commanders of two expeditions sent out by the Company of Merchant Adventurers, recorded their observations of the ice edge. Early charts are irregular and infrequent, reflecting the remoteness and hostility of the region. The frequency of observations generally increases over time, as the economic and strategic importance of the Arctic grew, along with the ability to access, observe and record information on sea ice. The Norwegian Meteorological Institute in Tromsø used a combination of satellite imagery and in situ observations to produce daily digital charts each working day. These show not only the ice edge, but also detailed information on the range of sea ice concentrations and ice types. The Norwegian Meteorological Institute is continuing this series, and more recent charts may be obtained from

Knowing how to manage your finances is important for any business. If you aren't sure how much money you have in your accounts, you won't be able to pay your bills. Overseeing cash flow is crucial for keeping your finances in order. However, the processes in the supply chain are changing, and you'll need an accounting method that will accommodate those switches.
What accounting methods are currently used?
Traditionally, there are two main techniques for overseeing the money coming in and going out of a company: accrual and cash. Both methods have their advantages and disadvantages. However, one may benefit the business more than the other depending on the size and income of the company.

igh the pros, cons and various approaches to major tasks or decisions. A decision tree can help executives break down the elements of a decision-making process and consider input from a range of participants. This type of approach is highly effective when used in brainstorming sessions and strategic planning meetings.
An individual decision tree should be used for each decision that must be made. Create the core or “trunk” for the tree using a whiteboard or large paper flipchart that is easy to write on and is visible to all participants. In the center of the core, briefly summarize the decision to be made. For example, if you are thinking about diversifying your product offerings, you would write “New product development?” in the core.
From the core of your tree, draw two main “branches” or lines that represent the pros and cons of the decision. Using the example of a new product introduction, pros might include increased earnings, entry

Pat Maloney passed away in the late summer of 2016. He'd been facing terminal cancer, and died at home in the village of Arden, Ontario, with his wife, Joanne Pickett, by his side. Their final years together were some of their strongest.
"We became the best of friends," she said. "We just spent such great time together. We took road trips, we talked a lot… We did all of the things that we hadn't taken the time to do before."
Maloney had been a father, a friend. He was a carpenter and a conversationalist, with a sharp wit and a sense of humour. He loved reading books and watching a good hockey game.
He also used to play the flute — but that was a very long time ago.

advocacy group founded by congressman and presidential candidate Ron Paul (R-TX), is gearing up for an "Internet freedom" project that focuses on opposing government regulation of the Internet.
A draft of the project's manifesto was first leaked by Buzzfeed. It warns that "collectivist special interests" are pushing for harmful Internet legislation.
According to "Internet collectivists," the document says, "'Net neutrality' means government acting as arbiter and enforcer of what it deems to be neutral." The document criticizes antitrust regulation of successful Internet companies and government micromanagement of everything from the electromagnetic spectrum to tech companies' privacy practices.

re-elected to serve a second five-year term, in a vote at the UN General Assembly in New York.
Mr Ban, a former South Korean foreign minister, was the only candidate after the UN Security Council unanimously recommended his re-election.
Critics say he is too deferential to major powers, but he has won praise for his policies on climate change and the protests sweeping the Middle East.
He took over at the UN in 2007.
His second term will formally begin on 1 January 2012 and run until the end of 2016.
Mr Ban smiled and bowed to ambassadors and diplomats gathered at UN headquarters, who backed the reappointment through applause without a vote.
